0.1 Lars

The previous "forgetting" bug has now been fixed but another problem has arisen as in
can we put a css margin on every image in #PageContent. If we do this using the main
css we will most definitely break things. Alternatively a solution using an if (path) {} to add the
css will create a lot of messy code. So the best solution i could come up with was using 
the newly created content:cdata field to sort this.

If anyone objects ( which i would understand ) or has a better of doing this then let me know!

Code in template:

<!-- Custom css field which allows you to add custom css to a particular
       page using the cms editor. For safety this field is set to style="display:none"
       and needs to manually be unhidden to be edited -->

      <content:cdata id="customCss" style="display:none;" />

<!-- end -->

Field content for example:
 <style type="text/css">#PageContent img { margin-right: 10px;}</style>

Sorted and looking good! ( to me )

http://dev.kitsite.com/kit/preview/about-us/the-people-delivering-the-games/the-london-organising-committee/locog-board.php

Just wanted to flag with you the closing of the GM application process.

The plan is to close public applications at midnight on 27 October. We will need to remove the link to the application form from the website - I should be able to do this myself as it's just editing the include. The link to the portal (Games Maker zone) remains. 

We will keep the specialist form open (though we will remove some codes/identifiers) until 12 November, when we will close that (but keep it available for reactiviation if we need to later). The easiest thing will probably be just to move it to a different place so the URL doesn't work. Again, I can almost certainly do this myself.
Marked as high. Assigned to Jamie for now.

Amend the Translation feed as follows, to integrate with applied language (AL):

1. Develop a way of calling AL's SOAP api via rhino (the language the feed is written in).
2. Liaise with AL re. exact workflow/process.
3. Write new outbound feed to push queued content into AL's translation queue.
4. Write new inbound feed to check for completion of outstanding jobs - if there are any, then retrieve them and import them into the CMS as per current feed.
5. Test!

The estimate is 10 days. I will keep track of the actual time spent in this ticket's comments.

Aug
1/4 day liaising with AL.
3/4 day developing SOAP client for rhino.

Running total: 1 day.

Aug: 1/2 day developing REST client for rhino.
Sept: 1 day conversing with Gareth, reading up on REST api and (mainly) trying to connect to their REST service. Have been a few teething problems, esp. wrt firewalls, vpns, dns, etc.

Running total: 2.5 days

Ticket #1102 "Translation - Send examples to A..." was closed and merged into this ticket.

Last Comment in #1102: Translation - Send examples to ALS / read up on API inital implementation test

Ticket #81 "Do not allow pages in a "Sent" s..." was closed and merged into this ticket.

Last Comment in #81: Have upped the priority, and also added an estimate of 1 day.
This is for Morag's (I think very sensible) idea.
Another option is to generate an message saying: "Sorry this page has already been sent for translation". This would be 0 days.
"Sorry, this page has already been sent, click HERE to forcibly re-send it" would be 1.5 days (kieran + janos).

Ticket #61 "Prevent certain pages (particula..." was closed and merged into this ticket.

Last Comment in #61: This one has been outstanding for several weeks and it's going to be very useful to have it in advance of (editorial) work starting on the redesign.

In the past, it has most obviously caused problems with the home page, so this is the place to start, but it is quite likely that we will want to add the workflow to other pages (presumably on a template by template basis).

subject: Translation - AL integration
description:
Amend the Translation feed as follows, to integrate with applied language (AL):

1. Develop a way of calling AL's SOAP api via rhino (the language the feed is written in).
2. Liaise with AL re. exact workflow/process.
3. Write new outbound feed to push queued content into AL's translation queue.
4. Write new inbound feed to check for completion of outstanding jobs - if there are any, then retrieve them and import them into the CMS as per current feed.
5. Test!

The estimate is 10 days. I will keep track of the actual time spent in this ticket's comments.

Hi Morag, as per telephone conversation, can you provide us with some guidance on:

1. Which pages should the shop widget appear on? (when I say pages, I mean which broad groups of pages, probably narrowed down by template, should the shop widget appear on). E.g. should it be on the home page, blog pages, events, etc.?

3. Should the shop widget go on French - language pages? NB We do not have translations of the product /names/. We can - obviously - display "Magasin" rather than "Shop" on the French pages.

Also, our test plan would be as follows: (NB This would follow extensive testing on Kitsite's dev server).

1. Switch off the rsync process, which mirrors web01 -> web2,3,4,..
2. Kitsite make CMS amendments to implement the new shop widget - i.e. add the shop widget to relevant pages (c. 1hr).
3. You/other to publish some pages.
4. You/other to check that the pages look ok on web01.
4.5. Back out changes if there'sa problem.
5. Switch on the rsync process.

I would estimate the process should take 3-4 hours, during which no editorial updates can be made.

There are - of course - other options, which I can discuss with you if the above is not acceptable.

(note to self - one option might be to disable the php shop code on all servers other than web01; I'm not 100% sure whether we can work out what server we're running on but ... it might be something to look into - will obv. result in more work on our part tho').

I'm sorry if it appears that I'm going round in circles here, but there's one really important thing that I need to know regarding this ticket: (NB capitals are for emphasis, rather than to indicate shouting!)

Are there any pages that:
 1. SHOULD appear in navigation but SHOULD NOT appear in search results.
 2. SHOULD NOT appear in navigation but SHOULD appear in search results.

If there ARE any such pages then this implies that we need a "hide-from-search" checkbox, as discussed earlier in this ticket.

Explanation/reminder: At present we have a "hide-from-navigation" checkbox which is used to denote pages that should NOT appear in automatic navigation (e.g. latest news, LH nav, etc.).
At some point, this flag has also been hijacked to also mean "hide-from-search".
This is obviously a problem if there are any pages that meet either (1.) or (2.) above.

As we attempted to indicate below, there aren’t any for point 1 but all the ones marked ‘ok to be found in search’ are ones that fit point 2. So i guess we need that check box... is it very complicated?

There has been quite a lot of picking-up / putting-down of this ticket, and has thus I think that the total will now be at the upper end of my estimate spectrum.
i.e. 1 day.
(worth noting that it's already at 0.3).
Kieran

Thanks for your help with the redirects. Everything went well last night in closing down the public application process - though sad to have to dismantle so much of our lovely work. :(

Although general public applications have now closed, we are still keeping the (hidden) specialist application form open for three more weeks, to allow partners and sponsors to complete their applications.

For this reason people will still be accessing the specialist form as well as the accessible form - so please don't remove them!

The other piece of work we still have to do is to swap in a static banner for the pink Flash banner at the top of every page - I hope to supply this in the next couple of days, and hope it wont' take too long to replace.

Thank you very much!

Morag
